message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Towards the Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs): A Comprehensive Review
Paper Abstract: Recently, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), also known as drones, have come in a great diversity of several applications such as military, construction, image and video mapping, medical, search and rescue, parcel delivery, hidden area exploration, oil rigs and power line monitoring, precision farming, wireless communication and aerial surveillance. The drone industry has been getting significant attention as a model of manufacturing, service and delivery convergence, introducing synergy with the coexistence of different emerging domains. UAVs offer implicit peculiarities such as increased airborne time and payload capabilities, swift mobility, and access to remote and disaster areas. Despite these potential features, including extensive variety of usage, high maneuverability, and cost-efficiency, drones are still limited in terms of battery endurance, flight autonomy and constrained flight time to perform persistent missions. Other critical concerns are battery endurance and the weight of drones, which must be kept low. Intuitively it is not suggested to load them with heavy batteries. This study highlights the importance of drones, goals and functionality problems. In this review, a comprehensive study on UAVs, swarms, types, classification, charging, and standardization is presented. In particular, UAV applications, challenges, and security issues are explored in the light of recent research studies and development. Finally, this review identifies the research gap and presents future research directions regarding UAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Drone carrier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drone_carrier"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned aircraft system simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aircraft_system_simulation"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"General Atomics MQ-9 Reaper - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Atomics_MQ-9_Reaper"},{"title":"Manned-unmanned teaming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_combat_aircraft"},{"title":"UPS Flight Forward - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UPS_Flight_Forward"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of drone aircraft based on the search results:

## Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## Types and Classifications

Drones come in many varieties. An unmanned combat aerial vehicle (UCAV), also known as a combat drone, fighter drone or battlefield UAV, is an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) that carries aircraft ordnance such as air-to-surface missiles, anti-tank guided missiles (ATGMs), and/or aerial bombs on hardpoints or within weapons bay.(no content)ICAO classifies unmanned aircraft as either remotely piloted aircraft or fully autonomous. Some UAVs offer intermediate degrees of autonomy. For example, a vehicle may be remotely piloted in most contexts but have an autonomous return-to-base operation.

## Applications

Drones have expanded far beyond military use. Firefighters, police, miners, and weather researchers are now using UAVs (commonly referred to as drones), which were first used in military sectors.(no content)UPS Flight Forward Inc. became the first company to receive the Federal Aviation Administration's full Part 135 Standard certification, allowing the company to operate an unlimited remote-controlled drone delivery network in the United States.

## Modern Technologies

Autonomous drones employ a host of advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.

I've performed a web search for "Wireless communication." Here are the key findings:

## Definition
Wireless communication is the transfer of information (telecommunication) between two or more points without the use of an electrical conductor, optical fiber or other continuous guided medium for the transfer.

## How It Works
Wireless communications can involve other electromagnetic phenomena, such as light and magnetic or electric fields, or the use of sound.(no content)The telecommunications industry uses wireless systems that use some form of energy (e.g. radio waves and acoustic energy) to transfer information without the use of wires.

## Common Applications
Modern wireless technologies include mobile broadband, Wi-Fi, and Bluetooth.(no content)Wireless operations permit services, such as mobile and interplanetary communications, that are impossible or impractical to implement with the use of wires.

## Historical Background
In 1894, Guglielmo Marconi began developing a wireless telegraph system using radio waves.(no content)The term wireless was revived in the 1980s and 1990s mainly to distinguish digital devices that communicate without wires, and this became its primary usage in the 2000s.

Web search results for query: "Swarm robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

## Swarm Robotics

Based on the search results, here's an overview of swarm robotics:

### Definition and Principles

Swarm robotic platforms apply swarm robotics in multi-robot collaboration.(no content)Unlike distributed robotic systems in general, swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots.

Key characteristics of swarm robotics include:
- Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities such as wireless transmission systems, do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish the given task.
- Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as the effect of thousands of small robots can maximize the effect of the swarm-intelligent approach.

### Inspiration and History

Swarm robotic platforms take inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.(no content)The phrase "swarm robotics" was reported to make its first appearance in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in early 2000s.

### Applications

There are many potential applications for swarm robotics, including tasks that demand miniaturization like distributed sensing tasks in micromachinery or the human body.(no content)A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks.

Web search results for query: "Search and rescue"

Links: [{"title":"Search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue"},{"title":"RAF Search and Rescue Force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RAF_Search_and_Rescue_Force"},{"title":"Combat search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Combat_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Urban search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"Mounted search and rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mounted_search_and_rescue"},{"title":"National Search and Rescue Agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Search_and_Rescue_Agency"},{"title":"Search and rescue dog - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_and_rescue_dog"},{"title":"National Association for Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Association_for_Search_and_Rescue"},{"title":"Storm Search and Rescue Tactical Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Storm_Search_and_Rescue_Tactical_Vehicle"},{"title":"Canadian Armed Forces Search and Rescue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canadian_Armed_Forces_Search_and_Rescue"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about search and rescue:

## Definition and Overview

Search and rescue (SAR) is the search for and provision of aid to people who are in distress or imminent danger.(no content)The general field of search and rescue includes many specialty sub-fields, typically determined by the type of terrain the search is conducted over.

## Types of Search and Rescue Operations

The field encompasses several specialized areas:

- **Urban Search and Rescue**: Urban search and rescue (USAR or US&R) is a type of technical rescue operation that involves the location, extrication, and initial medical stabilization of victims trapped in an urban area, namely structural collapse due to natural disasters, war, terrorism or accidents, mines and collapsed trenches.

- **Combat Search and Rescue**: Combat search and rescue (CSAR) are search and rescue operations that are carried out during war that are within or near combat zones.

- **Mountain Rescue**: Mountain rescue relates to search and rescue operations specifically in rugged and mountainous terrain.

- **Mounted Search and Rescue**: Mounted search and rescue (MSAR) is a specialty within search and rescue (SAR), using horses as search partners and for transportation to search for missing persons.

## Tools and Resources

A search-and-rescue (SAR) dog is a dog trained to respond to crime scenes, accidents, missing persons events, as well as natural or man-made disasters.(no content)Common dog breeds used for search-and-rescue work include German Shepherds, Labrador Retriever, Border Collies and Golden Retriever.

## Search Results: Autonomy in Artificial Intelligence

I found comprehensive information about autonomy in artificial intelligence. Here are the key findings:

### Basic Definition

An autonomous agent is an artificial intelligence (AI) system that can perform complex tasks independently.(no content)In artificial intelligence, an intelligent agent is an entity that perceives its environment, takes actions autonomously toachieve goals, and may improve its performance through machine learning or by acquiring knowledge.

### Autonomous Agents and Systems

According to Franklin and Graesser (1997), an autonomous agent is a system situated within and a part of an environment that senses that environment and acts on it, over time, in pursuit of its own agenda.(no content)In the context of generative artificial intelligence, AI agents are a class of intelligent agents distinguished by their ability to operate autonomously in complex environments. Agentic AI tools prioritize decision-making over content creation and do not require human prompts or continuous oversight. They possess several key attributes, including complex goal structures, natural language interfaces, the capacity to act independently of user supervision, and the integration of software tools or planning systems.

### Levels of Autonomy

Regarding the autonomy of AGI and associated risks, researchers define five levels: tool (fully in human control), consultant, collaborator, expert, and agent (fully autonomous).

### Applications

Autonomous AI systems are being deployed in various domains, including autonomous vehicles, which use artificial intelligence to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.

Mulla - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Mulla"},{"title":"Jancis Robinson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jancis_Robinson"}]

Here's what I found about precision agriculture:

## Definition and Purpose

Precision agriculture is a management strategy that gathers, processes and analyzes temporal, spatial and individual plant and animal data and combines it with other information to support management decisions according to estimated variability for improved resource use efficiency, productivity, quality, profitability and sustainability of agricultural production.(no content)It is used in both crop and livestock production.

## Key Technologies

The practice of precision agriculture has been enabled by the advent of GPS and GNSS.(no content)Tools include Variable rate technology (VRT), Global positioning system, Geographical information system, Grid sampling, and remote sensors.(no content)Precision agriculture can benefit from unmanned aerial vehicles that are relatively inexpensive and can be operated by novice pilots. These agricultural drones can be equipped with multispectral or RGB cameras to capture many images of a field.

## Benefits

Variable-rate application (VRA) technologies can apply precise amounts of water, fertilizer, pesticide, herbicide, etc., and a number of empirical studies find that VRA improves input use efficiency.(no content)Empirical evidence indicates precision agriculture technologies can increase yields.

## Historical Significance

Precision agriculture is a key component of the third wave of modern agricultural revolutions. With new technological advancements in the agricultural revolution of precision farming, each farmer will be able to feed 265 people on the same acreage.

Web search results for query: "Electric battery"

Links: [{"title":"Electric battery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_battery"},{"title":"Electric vehicle battery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_vehicle_battery"},{"title":"Battery electric vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battery_electric_vehicle"},{"title":"List of electric vehicle battery manufacturers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_electric_vehicle_battery_manufacturers"},{"title":"Category:Electric vehicle battery manufacturers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Electric_vehicle_battery_manufacturers"},{"title":"Category:Battery electric vehicle manufacturers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Battery_electric_vehicle_manufacturers"},{"title":"List of battery electric vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_battery_electric_vehicles"},{"title":"History of the battery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_the_battery"},{"title":"Plug-in electric vehicle fire - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plug-in_electric_vehicle_fire"},{"title":"Milwaukee Tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milwaukee_Tool"}]

I've performed a web search for "Electric battery" and found comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

An electric battery is a source of electric power consisting of one or more electrochemical cells with external connections for powering electrical devices.

## Types of Batteries

There are two main categories:

- **Primary Batteries**: Primary (single-use or "disposable") batteries are used once and discarded, as the electrode materials are irreversibly changed during discharge; a common example is the alkaline battery used for flashlights and a multitude of portable electronic devices.

- **Secondary Batteries**: Secondary (rechargeable) batteries can be discharged and recharged multiple times using an applied electric current; the original composition of the electrodes can be restored by reverse current. Examples include the lead–acid batteries used in vehicles and lithium-ion batteries used for portable electronics such as laptops and mobile phones.

## Historical Development

Italian physicist Alessandro Volta built and described the first electrochemical battery, the voltaic pile, in 1800. This was a stack of copper and zinc plates, separated by brine-soaked paper disks, that could produce a steady current for a considerable length of time.

## Modern Applications

Batteries come in many shapes and sizes, from miniature cells used to power hearing aids and wristwatches to, at the largest extreme, huge battery banks the size of rooms that provide standby or emergency power for telephone exchanges and computer data centers.

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicles in the United States military - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_the_United_States_military"},{"title":"412th Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Regiment (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/412th_Unmanned_Aerial_Vehicle_Regiment_(Ukraine)"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle applications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle_applications"},{"title":"Uncrewed vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned aerial vehicle manufacturers of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_aerial_vehicle_manufacturers_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicle-related incidents - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicle-related_incidents"}]

## Search Results for "Unmanned Aerial Vehicle"

Here's a comprehensive overview of unmanned aerial vehicles based on the search results:

### Definition

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

### History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

### Consumer Applications

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

### Civilian and Commercial Uses

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with Drone Industry Insights identifying "237 ways that drones revolutionize business" across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, and delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions.

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) or unmanned aircraft system (UAS), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.(no content)A UAV is capable of controlled, sustained level flight and is powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

### History

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)Significant development of drones started in the 1900s, and originally focused on providing practice targets for training military personnel.

### Consumer Applications

In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, laying out legal groundwork for consumer drone usage inside the United States.(no content)In 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone, priced at $629, which was considered one of the most influential consumer drone products ever made.

### Civilian and Commercial Uses

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with Drone Industry Insights identifying "237 ways that drones revolutionize business" across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, inspections for home insurance, counting wildlife, and delivering medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions.

Web search results for query: "Aerial surveillance"

Links: [{"title":"Aerial surveillance doctrine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerial_surveillance_doctrine"},{"title":"Unmanned surveillance and reconnaissance aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_surveillance_and_reconnaissance_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Surveillance aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance_aircraft"},{"title":"Aerial reconnaissance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerial_reconnaissance"},{"title":"Use of unmanned aerial vehicles in law enforcement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Use_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles_in_law_enforcement"},{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Reconnaissance aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reconnaissance_aircraft"},{"title":"Surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surveillance"},{"title":"CATUAV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CATUAV"},{"title":"421st Unmanned Systems Battalion (Ukraine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/421st_Unmanned_Systems_Battalion_(Ukraine)"}]

Here are the search results for "Aerial surveillance":

## Overview

Aerial surveillance is the gathering of surveillance, usually visual imagery or video, from an airborne vehicle—such as an unmanned aerial vehicle, helicopter, or spy plane.

## Legal Framework

In the United States, the aerial surveillance doctrine is the legal doctrine that under the Fourth Amendment, aerial surveillance of an individual's property does not inherently constitute a search for which law enforcement must obtain a warrant.(no content)In Florida v. Riley, the United States Supreme Court held that individuals do not have the right to privacy from police observation from public airspace.

## Technology and Capabilities

UAVs can be powerful surveillance tools by carrying camera systems capable of license plate scanning and thermal imaging, as well as radio equipment and other sensors.(no content)The MQ-9 Reaper, a U.S. drone plane used for domestic operations by the Department of Homeland Security, carries cameras that are capable of identifying an object the size of a milk carton from altitudes of 30,000 feet (9.1 km), and has forward-looking infrared devices that can detect the heat from a human body at distances of up to 60 kilometers (37 mi).

## Military and Law Enforcement Use

Surveillance aircraft are primarily operated by military forces and government agencies in roles including intelligence gathering, maritime patrol, battlefield and airspace surveillance.(no content)As of 2016, 167 police and fire departments in the United States purchased unmanned aerial vehicles, double the number that was purchased in 2015.

## Privacy Concerns

Several activists and organizations such as the Electronic Frontier Foundation, the American Civil Liberties Union, the Electronic Privacy Information Center, and progressive activist Jim Hightower have expressed privacy concerns over law enforcement use of UAVs for surveillance purposes.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name, relation, entity_type, wikipedia_url, relevance

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
